pros: Excellent leadership, clear expectations, fair salary
cons: Added on to excessive work load

pros: Great to work with students and professors. Worked as an E79 proctor.
cons: Recommend dimming the lights slightly. It's bright in there.

pros: nothing honestly its an all around good school
cons: theres a lot of work to be done, more than even ivy schools

pros: Flexible hours and reinforces knowledge
cons: Should pay more for established skills

review_title: Cool work for student, low pay
pros: It's cool to be in the Harvey Mudd makerspace and get paid Access to machines
cons: Low pay Not many hours

review_title: Minimal pay for extra cash as a student
pros: Grading courses helps develop a better understanding of the material
cons: Working while being a full time student can be very time consuming

pros: Consistent hours, overtime. Uniforms and tools provided.
cons: Long probation period. Management failed to accurately describe job at hire.

job_title: Summer Tour Guide in Claremont, CA
pros: Talk to a lot of people
cons:
Lots of walking
Persistent parents

review_title: Great benefits, super organized, poor leadership.
pros: Great benefits, very organized, good culture, great people.
cons: The president of the College is impulsive and is a poor leader.

pros: The professors are pretty chill and you really get to bond with the other Mudd students doing summer research
cons: The pay kind of really sucks, you spend more than half of your salary on housing if you can't get that covered by your research or financial aid

pros: Great professors to work with, students are excited to learn
cons: Lower pay than would be preferred

review_title: Grind culture, brilliant students, no work-life balance
job_title: Student Services Specialist in Claremont, CA
pros: Brilliant students, staff are mostly kind and generous humans, excellent HR, great health insurance and benefits package, pays more than state average for student services administrators.
cons: Grind culture, a few toxic personalities are entrenched and therefore tough to hold accountable, entire college is understaffed and overworked, hard to advance past entry level in some departments due to the way employees are characterized (salaried vs. hourly).

pros: Collaborative working environment, support from professors and fellow graders and tutors, enthusiastic students. There is limited flexibility in deadlines.
cons: Can be difficult to meet deadlines on busy weeks for grading. Be sure to communicate with fellow graders and professors if you're having a hard time!

pros: On the job training given
cons: 3D printers are often not working

pros: Good people fun job to work
cons: Work id sometimes slow during the year

pros: They seem pretty good to me
cons: They could definitely pay more

pros: The hours are very flexible
cons: The pay is too low

job_title: Associate Director of Annual Giving in Claremont, CA
pros: Flexible work from home during the pandemic
cons: It was a bit slow moving at times

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Claremont, CA
pros: Very valuable experience to work with students and learn material better.
cons: Experience depends a decent amount on the professor you're working for.

pros: Being able to help fellow students is very rewarding.
cons: Grading can be a time consuming task, make sure you have the time in your schedule to take on this role.

review_title: Being a Mudder is the most challenging and rewarding thing I have ever done
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You grow and learn as a person in incredible ways. The community is wildly supportive and there is always help when you need it. The college will push you to succeed and support you while they do.
cons: The work is hard. The hours are long. My brain stretched in new ways that hurt but have left me more capable.

pros: dedicated staff, challenging, engaging, resourceful, fun
cons: n/a, n/a, n/a, n/a, n/a

pros: Powerful reputation, good professors, strong academics, close knit community, ample opportunities for research etc.
cons: Big workload, the administration can be difficult to work with sometimes.

pros: supportive, friendly, lots of opportunity, flexible hours
cons: small, competitive, low pay, limited

pros: good benefits, fair pay, growth opportunities
cons: toxic work culture, not much student advocacy

pros: Being able to help other students
cons: Having to do it through Zoom

pros:
Friendly coworkers
Dining services/team is great
Parking is free
Students are interesting and creative
Several managers are leading their teams well
Extra paid holiday between Christmas and New Years
College/tuition benefits for children of staff (eligibility required)
Acceptable healthcare/dental/retirement plans
cons:
Outdated software and systems in department
Unattractive campus overall
Creative ideas are stifled by managers
Resources/tools to perform well at job not available
Older buildings with a lot of worn furniture in offices- boring environment
Not family friendly toward employees' work-life balance 
Culture of gossip-- everyone knows everyone else's business
Employees college-hop around the Claremont colleges
Micromanagement from administrators causes unproductiveness and tension 
Too many departmental meetings to discuss culture and values-- pointless
No tuition reimbursement policy for staff education (bachelors or masters degree pursuits)

pros: Working at the Linde Activities Center is great because it's on-campus, you get to meet a ton of people, staff, faculty, and students alike, and you can work on homework during your shift (provided you're paying attention to the rest of the facility, of course). Also, your coworkers in Facilities and Maintenance are some of the kindest, most caring people you'll meet.
cons: It's a student job, so the pay isn't great, but then again, it is part-time. Also, students are occasionally rude to you when their real problem is a cancelled class or something not in your control. Also, if you're a sophomore, you get the worst shifts generally.

review_title: The Best Undergraduate Engineering School in the Country ... and for good reason!
pros:
A dedicated cadre of super-smart faculty and staff who are committed to teaching undergraduate education.

Scary-smart students.

Beautiful campus infrastructure, including the best dining hall in all of The Claremont Colleges.

Ranked insanely well on all national surveys
cons:
Long-time employees tend to get crankier and crankier with each passing year

In some administrative arenas, opportunities for career advancement are limited

pros: Very friendly and supportive environment. There's a lot of smart people here to help you, and the food they serve during grading is so great.
cons: You eat so much food during grading that you gain 20 pounds. There is so many great people around you, that you are always motivated to succeed, and I needed to fill in words here, so don't mind this comment.

job_title: Instructional Assistant Professor in Claremont, CA
pros:
HMC has absolute fantastic students. Even they are not as prepared as you thought, they work really hard to make things work.

For those who never experience top American engineering education, this is the place that you will be amazed!

Your fellows are all friendly.
cons:
The nominal teaching load is not actually heavy. However, as the courses here are designed in a very aggressive way, you have a lot of things to prepare.

For a temporary faculty, you may face pretty stressful workload as you are working full-time and looking for a job at same time.

review_title: Harvey Mudd is a great place to work
pros: Flexible hours, many options for jobs. Graders get to pick their own hours and get to work with professors, and all of the professors are great at HMC. They also get food for free at "grading parties" and other perks, like free t-shirts for CS grutors.
cons: It's not a real job. You can't expect to get a lot of money from a grading job. But you will get valuable experience and the chance to help others learn. You might build relationships with other students and graders.

review_title: I was a grader/tutor for CSCI105 HM-01, the introductory Computer Systems course.
job_title: Grader and Tutor for Computer Science in Claremont, CA
pros: I enjoyed being able to go over the details of 32 and 64-bit signed/unsigned integer and float representation, gdb debugger, x86 executable disassembly, x86 buffer overflow attack, and web proxy implementation using the sockets interface in the C programming language.
cons: The pay is meager, but ultimately I worked part time and it was good pocket money. The main reward of the job that I had was in the continued learning and insight into how others learn.

pros: Great, though odd student culture. One of the top schools in the country even though it is not well known. Great benefits but try to negotiate more when hiring on.
cons: A lot of tension between those holding onto the old regime and those trying to bring in new things, though it is less in recent years. Pay is a bit low for expectations. Decision making is a long process.

job_title: Writing Assessment Specialist in Claremont, CA
pros: Team environment, highly collaborative, but still respectful of individual opinion and decisions.  Values intellectual ability and outspokenness.
cons: Only a short-term project; it would be nice if this was a regular process to which one could be rehired, perhaps, each semester, or annually.

pros: I have been a faculty member here for over a decade.  Mudd has a high degree of collegiality among the faculty, a strong sense of shared governance, and smart and motivated students.
cons: A lot of service work required of faculty.

pros: So many opportunities for on campus jobs here! Also, they pay well. Great for making money to get through college.
cons: Class is demanding so it his hard to commit to some work commitments

pros: Really great people to work with in the summer.
cons: Can be really busy being a mentor but totally worth it. Have to put in extra hours at nights with meeting with incoming freshmen

pros: Great faculty, teammates and resources. Learned a lot. Got my name on a paper as an undergrad.
cons: Pay isn't great and you have to deal with the Claremont summer.

job_title: Associate Director of Annual Giving in Claremont, CA
pros: Competitive Salaries, Small community/staff culture, parental leave policies
cons: Difficult fundraising environment, Manipulative Manager (who has since left HMC).

review_title: The work is meaningful and the supervisors are understanding.
pros: Flexible hours, meaningful work, and supervisors who care.
cons: Pay is not as great.

pros: Good work environment and friendly people
cons: Can be hard to find

pros: Teaching experience, good students, fun
cons: Small town, hot weather, desert

pros: It's easy and fun work
cons: poor pay and difficult hours

pros: I have done this before
cons: Takes time away from work
